Award.AwardTitle: Labor Market Outcomes of STEM Master's Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
In 2012, over 160,000 master's degrees were awarded in science and engineering fields by U.S. institutions; ten years earlier, it was less than 100,000. In some fields, the master's degree is the desired (if not required) qualification for initial employment and professional advancement. Accompanying the growth and labor market need is an assessment by the Bureau of Labor Statistics that jobs that require a master's degree at entry-level will grow by 18% in the next decade. As the number of master's degree holders in the U.S. economy grows, it is critically important to understand how these individuals have an impact on the U.S. S&E enterprise. The purpose of this project is to examine workforce outcomes, career mobility and the value of a master's education in science and engineering in the U.S. The project seeks to enrich discussions about continued public support for and investment in master's education, and suggest a framework for linking the production of master's degrees with workforce and economic goals using national data collection efforts as the centerpiece.

The project will produce original research that employs data from the National Survey of College Graduates (NSCG) to broadly explore these domains of inquiry: migration, career mobility, and individual monetary and non-monetary benefit-cost relations for master's education. The project will include a stakeholder meeting to synthesize findings of the research with insights from graduate deans, workforce and industry leaders and federal data experts focused on three questions: (1) How can existing data be used as metrics for labor market outcomes assessment of master's education?; (2) How can existing data facilitate alignment between master's education and workforce needs at the national and regional levels?; and 3) How can current national data collection efforts, including the NSCG, be augmented to better capture other labor market outcomes' assessment metrics, such as subsequent career mobility and satisfaction of master's degree holders?

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 2016, over 160,000 master's degrees were awarded in science and engineering fields by U.S. institutions; ten years earlier, it was less than 100,000. In some fields, the master's degree is the desired (if not required) qualification for initial employment and professional advancement. Additional evidence of labor market needs from the Bureau of Labor Statistics projects that jobs that require a master's degree at entry-level will grow by 18% in the next decade. As the number of master's degree holders in the U.S. economy grows, it is critically important to understand how these individuals have an impact on the U.S. S&E enterprise. The purpose of this project is to examine workforce outcomes, thus an aspect of the value of a master's education in science and engineering in the U.S.

 

Using the 2013 National Survey of College Graduates (NSCG), we examined three measures of the labor market outcomes of science and engineering master degree holders: annual earnings, primary work activity, and job relatedness, in comparison with individuals with only science and engineering bachelor degrees, master degree holders in non-science and engineering disciplines, and science and engineering PhD holders.  Though degree level (e.g., bachelor’s degree v. master’s degree v. PhD degree) correlates with individuals’ earning, the findings suggested that other factors such as primary work activities, fields of occupation, and employment sectors, as well as broad fields of study, relatedness of job to field of highest degree, current postsecondary enrollment status, gender, and race/ethnicity also explain one’s earning beyond degree premiums. Results show a distinct pay gap between male and female employees. The findings suggested that women are disadvantaged in almost every circumstance after controlling for other variables of interest, such as field of study, primary work activities, occupational field, employer sector, and race/ethnicity. While STEM master’s degree attainment is related to professionalization and specialization of one’s career, we also found that advancement to managerial roles is more closely related to one’s tenure in the workforce than to master’s degree attainment in some fields. This suggests that the relationship between master’s degrees and job responsibilities and professional advancements may vary by fields to which students receive their graduate training.

 

Overall, our study indicates that a salary premium for the master’s degree varies by fields. Furthermore, we found that women are disadvantaged in terms of their earnings even after controlling for field of study, primary work activities, occupational field, employer sector, and race and ethnicity. These findings have implications for policy and practice for broadening career participation and pathways, supporting career success for STEM master’s education. These results also suggested to us that more granular and nuanced findings on labor market outcomes can also serve as a tool for better career advising for prospective and current master’s students, as well as master’s programs. Having insights at more granular fields and occupational levels are useful in career advising and in helping to facilitate informed career decision making for students on a micro level.

 

This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.

 


Last Modified: 12/17/2018
Modified by: Hironao Okahana

Though degree level (e.g., bachelor?s degree v. master?s degree v. PhD degree) correlates with individuals? earning, the findings suggested that other factors such as primary work activities, fields of occupation, and employment sectors, as well as broad fields of study, relatedness of job to field of highest degree, current postsecondary enrollment status, gender, and race/ethnicity also explain one?s earning beyond degree premiums. While STEM master?s degree attainment is related to professionalization and specialization of one?s career, we also found that advancement to managerial roles is more closely related to one?s tenure in the workforce than to master?s degree attainment in some fields. This suggests that the relationship between master?s degrees and job responsibilities and professional advancements may vary by fields to which students receive their graduate training. Overall, our study indicates that a salary premium for the master?s degree varies by fields. Furthermore, we found that women are disadvantaged in terms of their earnings even after controlling for field of study, primary work activities, occupational field, employer sector, and race and ethnicity. These findings have implications for policy and practice for broadening career participation and pathways, supporting career success for STEM master?s education. Having insights at more granular fields and occupational levels are useful in career advising and in helping to facilitate informed career decision making for students on a micro level.
